text:
I grew up in the times of the Gameboy, the
Super Nintendo and the N64.

When recently traveling Japan I felt quite
some retro vibes and just had to purchased
a SNES Classic Mini when back home.

Transparent consoles and gamepads were the
hip thing back in the 90s and I wanted to
make my new classic mini unique.

So I 3D scanned the housing of a controller
and 3D printed replicas in resin.
Lets find out more!

Guten Tag everybody, I’m Stefan and welcome
to CNC Kitchen!
This video is sponsored by Nord VPN.
More and them and my trip to Japan later.

I can remember that even since I was a small
boy I always wanted one of these Gameboys
that had the transparent housings.

Since I was very interested in in electronics
and technology, it was so great, being able

to take a look at the guts of one of these
devices.
Well, I never got one.

That’s probably why I ended up as a mechanical
and not an electrical engineer.

Anyways, during my recent holiday in Japan,
we visited Super Potato, a retro gaming store
in Tokyo.

3 stories full of Super Famicom, Sega Genesis
and everything else desirable.

After playing a couple of arcades and seeing
all of these consoles of my childhood, I had

to directly purchased a Super Nintendo Classic
Mini to play some old classics back home.

The only thing missing was a cool gamepad
to really take me back to when I was a small
boy.

Since I still had the GOM Atos Core, a professional
3D scanner, at my disposal, I thought it might

be great and interesting project to 3D scan
the injection molded housing of a gamepad

and then print them out in clear resin on
a 3D printer.

The GOM Atos Core that GOM kindly provided
for a couple of weeks for my research and

video is a structured light scanner that consists
out of a projector and 2 cameras.

It projects a line patter on the object that
you are scanning and then calculates the shape

of the part by evaluating how the pattern
is deflected.

The cool thing about such a professional machine
is that it’s calibrated and therefore the
scans are really perfectly to size.

You scan a part in several steps because each
scan only captures the part of the object
that is visible at that point.

Eventually you take shots from several perspectives
and match them together using refence point
sticker.

Even though the injection molds I wanted to
scan didn’t look particularly complex they

were a bit challenging to scan because you
need a lot of different shots to capture the
whole part.

I could have put a ton of reference points
on the parts and scan them that way but that

seemed wasteful and more importantly, at the
locations of the stickers, the geometry is
slightly altered.

In order to perform such a task, experts use
reference frames around such objects that
are held in the frame by studs.

This way the part doesn’t need to be marked
and all shots can be referenced with the surrounding
frame.

I didn’t have one of those, so I made one
myself.

I bought 15x15mm aluminum profiles in the
hardware store and cut pieces using a miter

saw to get a rectangle a bit bigger that the
parts I wanted to scan.

The part will later be held in place by M4
threaded rod, so for simplicity I already
drilled holes and cut threads in the pieces.

Probably 10 years ago I bought a bag of aluminum
solder or brazing rod that I finally wanted

to try out to put the pieces together to form
a whole frame.

TIG welding would have been the better option,
but unfortunately, I don’t own a welder.
Using the brazing rod requires a bit of preparation.

Basically most aluminum that I can buy here
in the hardware store is anodized and that
will ruin your day while brazing.

This is why I used a file to reveal the bare
metal at all of the locations.

Brazing itself is not too hard and is in a
way similar to soldering copper wire.

The issue with aluminum brazing is that you
need to keep your part hot during that process

so that the material can flow where it needs
to.
This is why many struggle brazing bigger parts.

Aluminum is unfortunately a good conductor
of heat so the heat of your torch will be
gone in no time.

I tackled that by kind of floating the part
on just a couple of studs.

This doesn’t reduce heat conduction but
will prevent that the heat sinks into the
working surface I used.

I clamped everything in place, heated the
joint and rubbed the brazing rod on the corner

from time to time until the melting temperature
of the rod was reached, which is by the way

a good bit lower than the melting point of
aluminum.

This was then repeated for the rest of the
corners until I got a nice and very sturdy
frame.

I painted it matt black so it’s less likely
to be picked up during the scanning process.

I then added a bunch of reference points for
scan alignment because you need at least 3

points visible in each scan that the alignment
process works.

Finally, I mounted the gamepad housing using
the threaded rods of which I sharpened the
tips a little to not block too much scan area.

I screwed the rods until they touched the
part and increased the stiffness by tightening
a counter-nut.

The part is then held in position via a drop
of superglue because it needs to be properly

secured into place and you can’t clamp the
part because that will deform its shape and
therefore make the scan useless.

I scanned the parts from many different angles
from the top and the bottom.

The refence frame ensured that the software
was able to match them all up into one complete
part.

The scan itself only gives you a point cloud
that at first, even still contains parts of

the reference frame and the threaded rods
but that can be selected and removed.

After that step the point cloud is converted
to a surface mesh so basically the final STL.

Unfortunately, there were areas that I wasn’t
able to reach during scanning due to the tight

spaces and also at the locations of the fixtures
there are still holes in the model.

For the 3D printing process, the mesh needs
to be closed and watertight.

This is done by a simple hole closing tool
that locates the voids and then closes them

with additional surfaces taking the curvature
of the surrounding into consideration.

And there we have it, two beautiful 3D scans
of the SNES classic mini gamepad shells.

I was really impressed by the amount of details
I was able to get from the 3D scans.
Really beautiful.

Just on a side note: If you like this video
then please consider subscribing and also
click the bell to not miss any upcoming videos!

These models could now be printed out but
as I said before, there were some spots that

I couldn’t reach but that are functionally
important.

So the through holes that hold the shells
together are mostly closed and also the slots
for the shoulder buttons are not perfect.

For this reason I went into Fusion 360, loaded
the scanned data and just created simple shapes

at the locations where I want to remove the
material.

Unfortunately, you can’t perform boolean
operations on meshes in Fusion so that’s

why I exported the bodies that need to be
removed as additional STLs and imported them

into Microsofts 3D builder in which you can
substract two bodies from each other very
easily.

So now the only thing that is left is to export
the edited mesh and we are ready to print.

Similar to FMD 3D prints, resin prints also
need to be supported during the printing process.

I used Prusa Slicer 2.1 for support generation
in which I loaded the part and rotated it
in a way so that it fit the build volume.

The automatic supports already help to find
many of the critical locations but a couple

of test prints showed me that there were specific
areas where I had to place even a bit more
than suggested.

The fully supported model is then exported
once again and sent to the resin printer using
their proprietary software.

The resin printer that I used is the DAZZ
3D L120 which is a so called MSLA or Masked
SLA printer.

Just for clarification, I don’t really recommend
it due to it’s horrible software.

If you want a resin printer maybe buy something
different, I just don’t have anything else.

The machine basically consists out of a UV
LED, an LCD screen, a resin vat and a movable
build platform.

The model that we print is sliced into 50µm
thick layers which results in a stack of images

that are white in the regions where material
will be and black everywhere else.

The printer now loads these images in successive
order and puts them on the screen allowing

the UV light only to pass in the white areas
where the resin cures.

The particular resin that I used was ANYCUBICs
clear resin that was very pleasant to use
with only minimal odor.

The build platform is lifted and lowered after
each layer so that new resin can flow into
the curing area.

After 10 hours and more than 1000 layers the
print was finished and really looks stunning!

After removing it from the platform and washing
it thoroughly in rubbing alcohol, it’s fully

cured using a UV light or just the sun, if
available.

Removing the supports is very easy and it
feels kind of similar to a Valcro strip.

The supports on these parts are a bit wasteful
and make up 50% of the final resin consumption
but I didn’t find a better solution.

Unfortunately, the parts lost a bit of their
transparency during the cleaning process because
they still have a bit of micro roughness.

Looking at the part under a microscope shows
the individual pixels of the screen, forming
the voxels of the part.
Looks kind of like a miniature Minecraft landscape.

To restore some of the transparency I coated
the parts in a couple of layers of clear coat

which smooths out the surface and gives it
a really nice look.
And there we have it!

The only thing still necessary is installing
the electronics and putting it back together.

I was really impressed how well the both printed
halfs fit together.

Only the upper and lower sides are a bit deformed
from the printing process but that isn’t
that bad.

Out of curiosity I also 3D scanned one of
the printed test parts and checked it for

accuracy and it was impressive to see how
well this whole copying process worked out.
All right, that’s it!

Let me know in the comments what you think
of this project and if you also have fond
memories of your childhood consoles.

So I got the idea for this project on my recent
and awesome 3 week trip to Japan where we
stayed many different places.

This also meant that I had to use a ton of
public wifi spots where, in the past, I was

always worried what’s been done with my
data and who might be sniffing it.

This time I constantly used NordVPN, who is
todays video sponsor, on all of my devices.

A VPN creates a secure and encrypted tunnel
for all of your data if you for example use
a free wifi.

NordVPN is a great solution if you’re worried
about online security and your private data.

They have apps and plugins for all of your
devices.

So as soon as you log onto a public wifi,
NordVPN connects to one of their over 1000

servers that they have in 61 countries and
then uses military grade encryption for all

outgoing and incoming data from your device
without sacrificing speed.

In the past, I already had weird postings
from my Facebook account after another holiday
because I used the hotel wifi.

NordVPN now gives me the confidence to use
my devices anywhere without danger.

If you’re regularly in the same position
or for example want to access geo-restricted
information, I highly recommend to use NordVPN.

Thank you NordVPN for sponsoring this episode!
Thank you for watching!
I hope you enjoyed this little project I made.

If so then don’t forget to leave a like,
subscribe to the channel and hit the bell!

If you want to help me make these videos then
please consider becoming a Patron or help
me out in other ways!

Also take a look at my other videos available
on this channel, I’m sure you’ll like
them.

I hope to have you around in the next one,
auf wiedersehen and goodbye!
